questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents to the clinic with complaints of chronic diarrhea, bloating, abdominal pain, and unintentional weight loss for the past few months. She mentions that these symptoms worsen after consuming foods containing barley. Laboratory investigations reveal iron deficiency anemia and elevated tissue transglutaminase antibodies (tTG-IgA). Which of the following will be the appropriate treatment for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Initiating a diet rich in barley to assess tolerance

options.label: C
options.text: Prescribing antibiotics to treat potential bacterial overgrowth

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with chronic diarrhea, bloating, and weight loss over the past few months. She reports feeling fatigued despite adequate rest. Physical examination reveals mild pallor and abdominal distension. Laboratory investigations show microcytic anemia with low serum iron and ferritin levels. The physician suspects a malabsorption syndrome. Which of the following diagnostic tests would confirm the diagnosis of celiac disease in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy with biopsy of duodenal mucosa

options.label: B
options.text: Colonoscopy with biopsy of colonic mucosa

options.label: D
options.text: Hydrogen breath test for lactose intolerance

questions.correct_answer: A. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy with biopsy of duodenal mucosa

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents with chronic diarrhea, abdominal bloating, and fatigue for several months. She reports irregular bowel habits and unintentional weight loss. Laboratory investigations reveal microcytic anemia with low serum iron and ferritin levels. Serological testing shows elevated levels of anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies (anti-tTG IgA). A small intestinal mucosal biopsy is performed, revealing histopathological changes consistent with hyperplastic crypts with partial villous atrophy. Which of the following Marsh classifications best describes the histopathological findings in this patient?
questions.explanation:

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with chronic diarrhea, steatorrhea, and weight loss over the past few months. Upon further evaluation, he is found to have deficiencies in fat-soluble vitamins. Which of the following mechanisms best explains the underlying cause of his symptoms?

options.label: A
options.text: Insufficient bile salt synthesis leads to impaired emulsification of fats.

options.label: B
options.text: Reduced absorption of short-chain fatty acids in the colon.

options.label: C
options.text: Hyposecretion of fibroblast growth factor 19 (FGF19) causes inhibition of bile acid synthesis.

options.label: D
options.text: Defective assembly of chylomicrons due to apolipoprotein deficiency.

questions.correct_answer: A. Insufficient bile salt synthesis leads to impaired emulsification of fats.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with complaints of joint pain and stiffness persisting for the past 6 years. He also reports significant unintentional weight loss, chronic diarrhea, and intermittent abdominal pain. On examination, he appears malnourished with signs of cachexia. Laboratory investigations reveal anemia and hypoalbuminemia. Biopsy shows PAS-positive macrophages. What condition is most likely responsible for the patient's clinical presentation?

A 45-year-old male presents with a history of chronic diarrhea, weight loss, arthralgia, and migratory polyarthritis. On examination, he has bilateral lymphadenopathy and a low-grade fever. Laboratory investigations reveal macrocytic anemia, hypoalbuminemia, and elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR). Which of the following is incorrect about the causative agent responsible for these clinical findings?

options.label: C
options.text: Fluoroquinolones are effective against the causative agent

options.label: D
options.text: Cotrimoxazole is used in maintenance therapy in the disease caused by this organism

questions.correct_answer: C. Fluoroquinolones are effective against the causative agent
questions.explanation:
Initial phase (IV)

Maintenance phase (Oral)
  • Ceftriaxone or Penicillin G for 2 weeks.
 

(OR)

 
  • Meropenem for 2 to 4 weeks.

(In case of ceftriaxone or penicillin allergy)
  • Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (Cotrimoxazole) for one year (Option D ruled out).
 

(OR)

 
  • Doxycycline + Hydroxycholoquine for one year.

(In case of Sulfa allergy)

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with a 6-month history of progressive memory loss and confusion. He also complains of intermittent episodes of involuntary eye and facial movements. On examination, he is noted to have supranuclear gaze palsy. His medical history is significant for chronic diarrhea, weight loss, and joint pain. Further investigations reveal periodic acid-Schiff (PAS)-positive macrophages in the cerebrospinal fluid. Which neurological manifestations are considered pathognomonic for the patient’s condition?
questions.correct_answer: D. Oculomasticatory myorhythmia and oculofacial myorhythmia

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with complaints of bloating, abdominal cramps, and diarrhea that occur consistently within 30 minutes to 2 hours after consuming dairy products. He reports no blood in the stool and denies weight loss or fever. His symptoms started several months ago and are relieved when he avoids milk and milk-based products. Laboratory tests reveal normal complete blood count and inflammatory markers. All of the following are true about this patient's condition except:

options.label: A
options.text: It can be confirmed using a hydrogen breath test.

options.label: B
options.text: Dietary calcium supplementation may be necessary to prevent deficiencies.

options.label: C
options.text: The condition involves an immune-mediated response to dairy proteins.

options.label: D
options.text: These patients have elevated luminal lactose levels upon ingestion of lactose.

questions.correct_answer: C. The condition involves an immune-mediated response to dairy proteins.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with chronic diarrhea, weight loss, and fatigue for 6 months. She gave a history of traveling to Southeast Asia, where she consumed untreated water. On examination, she is mildly anemic. Laboratory tests show microcytic anemia and low levels of vitamin B12 and folate. A small bowel biopsy reveals mild villous atrophy. Which organism is most commonly associated with this condition?

A 5-year-old child presents with chronic diarrhea, failure to thrive, and progressive night blindness. The child’s mother reports the presence of greasy, foul-smelling stools, and the child has not been gaining weight appropriately for the past year. Physical examination reveals mild abdominal distension. Laboratory studies show low cholesterol, triglycerides, and fat-soluble vitamins E and A. A small bowel biopsy reveals lipid-laden enterocytes. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 50-year-old woman presents with chronic diarrhea, bloating, and unintentional weight loss. She has a history of scleroderma, which has caused gastrointestinal motility issues. On examination, she shows signs of vitamin B12 deficiency. Which of the following is NOT a recognized cause of small bowel bacterial overgrowth in this patient?

Which of the following statements about protein-losing enteropathy (PLE) are correct? PLE can be caused by mucosal ulceration, such as in ulcerative colitis and GI carcinomas, leading to protein loss through damaged mucosa. Lymphopenia may be seen. PLE caused by lymphatic obstruction is most effectively treated with immunosuppressive agents like methotrexate. Alpha-1 antitrypsin testing in stool is diagnostic for PLE, with an elevated level confirming the diagnosis. A diagnosis of PLE is confirmed by measuring serum protein levels, which will show selective loss of only albumin.
questions.explanation:
Mucosal ulceration
  • Loss of blood and proteins
    • E.g.: Ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease
  • Seen in GI carcinoma (Statement 1)

Altered blood permeability

  • Crypt hyperplasia – celiac sprue
  • Explains protein loss and muscle wasting

Lymphatic dysfunction
  • Enlarged lymph nodes
    • Seen in Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma
  • High protein loss due to obstruction
  • Intestinal lymphangiectasia: Biopsy –
    • Normal enterocytes with dilated lymphatics
    • Clubbing of the villi
    • Diagnosis based on small intestinal mucosal biopsy
  • Cardiovascular causes: Constrictive pericarditis
    • Fontan physiology: Pediatrics
    • Back pressure will affect the lymphatic changes

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT typically used in the initial evaluation of malabsorption?
questions.explanation:
Patient History
  • GI Symptoms:
    • Abdominal pain
    • Diarrhea
    • Weight loss
    • Bloating
    • Fatigue/weakness
  • Signs of Nutrient Deficiencies:
    • Iron deficiency anemia (nail spooning)
    • Vitamin D & calcium deficiency (bone pain, fractures)
    • Vitamin B12 deficiency (peripheral neuropathy)
    • Protein deficiency (hair loss)
  • Medical History:
    • Chronic pancreatitis
    • Liver disease (primary biliary cholangitis, primary sclerosing cholangitis)
    • Small-bowel resection (e.g., Crohn’s disease, trauma, ischemic bowel disease)
  • Travel History:
    • To rule out infectious causes
  • Risk Factors:
    • Prior GI surgery, infections, or diseases affecting absorption

Physical Examination

Signs of Nutritional Deficiency:

  • Bitemporal wasting (weight loss)
  • Decreased mid-arm circumference
  • Nail spooning (Iron deficiency anemia)
  • Cheilosis (Vitamin B deficiency)
  • Peripheral neuropathy (Vitamin B12 deficiency)

Signs of Malabsorption:

  • Weight loss, edema, bloating, hair loss

Laboratory Tests

Basic Labs:

  • Hemoglobin (Hb) - To check for anemia
  • Serum ferritin - Iron deficiency anemia
  • INR (Prothrombin time) - Vitamin K deficiency (fat-soluble vitamins)
  • Serum carotene - Fat malabsorption
 

Specific Malabsorption Tests:

  • Stool tests:
    • Sudan III stain - Qualitative test for steatorrhea (fecal fat)
    • Stool elastase - To diagnose pancreatic insufficiency
  • Stool osmolar gap - For osmotic vs secretory diarrhea:
 

290 – 2 (stool [Na+] + stool [K+])
 
  • Osmotic diarrhea: Gap >50-100
  • Secretory diarrhea: Gap <50
 

Urinary D-xylose test: Carbohydrate malabsorption (especially for duodenal disease)

  • Excretion <4.5g suggests mucosal damage in the proximal small bowel.

Imaging Studies

Radiological Exams:

  • Barium small-bowel follow-through - To detect diseases like Crohn’s, celiac, diverticulosis.
  • MRI enterography (MRE) or CT enterography - To assess for inflammatory diseases like Crohn’s disease, strictures, and visualize hepatobiliary system.

Endoscopy:

  • Upper endoscopy with small-bowel biopsy - For suspected mucosal disease, e.g., celiac disease, Whipple’s disease, lymphoma.
  • Capsule endoscopy - For visualization of the entire small intestine if endoscopy is inconclusive.
  • Small-bowel enteroscopy

Endoscopic Findings and Biopsy Analysis

Diffuse Mucosal Pathology:

  • Whipple’s disease: PAS-positive macrophages (diagnosed with immunohistochemistry)
  • Agammaglobulinemia: Reduced plasma cells, normal or flat mucosal architecture
  • Abetalipoproteinemia: Vacuolated enterocytes post-prandially

Patchy Lesions:

  • Lymphoma: Malignant cells in lamina propria and submucosa
  • Lymphangiectasia: Dilated lymphatics in submucosa with protein loss (hypoproteinemia)

Nonspecific Findings:

  • Villus atrophy: Celiac disease, tropical sprue, bacterial overgrowth
  • Crypt hyperplasia: Celiac sprue, extensive tropical sprue
  • Eosinophilic gastroenteritis: Eosinophilic infiltrate (may be patchy)

Confirmatory Diagnosis and Treatment

Celiac Disease:

  • IgA tissue transglutaminase (tTG) antibody and IgG deamidated gliadin peptide antibody.
  • Gluten-free diet (monitor with follow-up antibody titers).

Whipple's Disease:

  • PAS-positive macrophages in biopsy.
  • Antibiotic therapy (Ceftriaxone + broad-spectrum antibiotics).

Tropical Sprue:

  • Clinical diagnosis; biopsy may show villous atrophy.
  • Antibiotics (Empirical treatment with tetracycline or folic acid).

Pancreatic Insufficiency:

  • Stool elastase levels.
  • Pancreatic enzyme replacement.

Lymphangiectasia:

  • Biopsy: Dilated lymphatics in submucosa.
  • Treatment: Low-fat, high-protein diet; medium-chain triglycerides.

Follow-Up and Monitoring
  • Nutrient deficiency monitoring (Iron, B12, Vitamin D/E/K)
  • Dietary adjustments (e.g., gluten-free, enzyme replacement)
  • Reassess with imaging/endoscopy if symptoms persist.
